(2018) }} "'''Say Amen (Saturday Night)'''" is a song by American [[pop rock]] band [[Panic! at the Disco]] from their sixth studio album, ''[[Pray for the Wicked]]'' (2018). It was released as the lead single for the album on March 21, 2018. The song became Panic! at the Disco's first number one single on the ''Billboard'' [[Alternative Songs]] chart in June 2018. ==Release== "Say Amen (Saturday Night)" was released for [[Digital distribution|digital download]] and [[streaming media|streaming]] on March 21, 2018 and was produced by Jake Sinclair and Imad Royal.[http://www.nme.com/news/music/panic-at-the-disco-new-album-pray-for-the-wicked-new-single-video-say-amen-saturday-night-north-american-tour-dates-tickets-brendon-urie-2270853 "NME article"], ''NME'', March 21, 2018. Retrieved on March 21, 2018. On the same day, the promotional single "(Fuck A) Silver Lining" was released.{{cite web|first=Monique|last=Melendez|url=https://www.spin.com/2018/03/panic-at-the-disco-say-amen-saturday-night-fuck-a-silver-lining/|title=Panic! at the Disco — “Say Amen (Saturday Night)” / “(Fuck A) Silver Lining”|publisher=Spin|date=March 21, 2018|accessdate=March 21, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ImadRoyal/status/976528733627588608|title=🤴🏻 on Twitter|publisher=}} The song became Panic! at the Disco's first number one single on the ''Billboard'' [[Alternative Songs]] chart in June 2018.{{cite web |title=Panic! at the Disco's 'Pray for the Wicked' Set for No. 1 Debut on Billboard 200 Chart |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8462806/panic-at-the-disco-pray-for-the-wicked-album-billboard-200 |website=Billboard |accessdate=26 June 2018}} ==Music video== Directed by [[Cloud (dancer)|Daniel "Cloud" Campos]], the music video for "Say Amen (Saturday Night)" premiered on March 21, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/8257063/panic-at-the-disco-new-album-tour-pray-for-the-wicked|title=Panic! at the Disco Announces New Album & Arena Tour: Hear New Song 'Say Amen (Saturday Night)'|publisher=}} Panic! at the Disco frontman [[Brendon Urie]] confirmed that the music video serves as a prequel to the band's 2013 music video, "[[This Is Gospel (song)|This Is Gospel]]", from the band's fourth studio album ''[[Too Weird to Live, Too Rare to Die!]]'' and the 2015 music video for "[[Emperor's New Clothes (song)|Emperor's New Clothes]]," from the band's fifth studio album ''[[Death of a Bachelor]].'' It begins with a news flash explaining that an artifact has been stolen. It cuts to burglars breaking into a house with crowbars, knives and other weapons. They walk to a bathroom, when Urie’s phone goes off, and Urie walks out of the bathroom door, seeing the burglars. He lassoes one into a fan with a belt, and kills the others shortly after. He goes to the kitchen and cuts off one’s hand, tips a scalding pan into one’s face, stabs two, and ploughs a potato on a knife into one’s face. He goes to the soundroom and blasts a few away with giant speakers, and then throws dynamite into a crowd of them. The doorbell goes off, and Urie walks over to see his girlfriend, they hug their way to the bedroom, and strip, but the girl notices that Urie stole the artefact, kicks him , and hits him across the face with a bat. Then she steals the key from Urie’s corpse. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download | title1 = Say Amen (Saturday Night) | length1 = 3:09 }} {{ Track listing | headline = Say Amen for Silver Linings | total_length = 5:58 | title1 = Say Amen (Saturday Night) | length1 = 3:09 | title2 = (Fuck A) Silver Lining | length2 = 2:49 }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2018) ! scope="col"| Peak
position |- ! scope="row"| Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2018/3/aria-chart-watch-466/|title=ARIA Chart Watch #466|publisher=auspOp|date=March 31, 2018|accessdate=March 31, 2018}} | 90 |- ! scope="row"| Canada ([[Hot Canadian Digital Songs]]){{cite web|title=Panic at the Disco Chart History (Hot Canadian Digital Song Sales)|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/Panic-at-the-Disco/chart-history/hot-canada-digital-song-sales|website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=May 22, 2018}} | 48 |- {{single chart|Billboardcanadarock|35|artist=Panic at the Disco|rowheader=true|accessdate=May 22, 2018}} |- {{single chart|Czech Republic|6|year=2018|week=31|rowheader=true|accessdate=August 7, 2018}} |- ! scope="row"| New Zealand Heatseekers ([[Recorded Music NZ|RMNZ]]){{cite web|url=https://nztop40.co.nz/chart/singles?chart=4469|title=NZ Heatseeker Singles Chart|publisher=[[Recorded Music NZ]]|date=April 2, 2018|accessdate=March 30, 2018}} | 2 |- {{single chart|Scotland|37|date=20180330|rowheader=true|accessdate=March 31, 2018}} |- {{single chart|UK|48|date=20180330|rowheader=true|accessdate=March 31, 2018}} |- {{single chart|Billboardhot100|60|artist=Panic at the Disco|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 3, 2018}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardalternativesongs|1|artist=Panic at the Disco|rowheader=true}} |- {{single chart|Billboardrocksongs|5|artist=Panic at the Disco|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 3, 2018}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardrockairplay|4|artist=Panic at the Disco|rowheader=true|accessdate=June 19, 2018}} |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Panic! at the Disco}} [[Category:2018 singles]] [[Category:Panic! at the Disco songs]] [[Category:Billboard Alternative Songs number-one singles]] [[Category:Songs critical of religion]] [[Category:Songs written by Jake Sinclair (songwriter)]] [[Category:Songs written by Lolo (singer)]] [[Category:Songs written by Brendon Urie]] [[Category:Songs written by Sam Hollander]]

{{See also|Religion and sexuality}} [[Human sexuality|Sexuality]] has a prominent role within the theology of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), which teaches that [[gender]] is defined in the [[premortal existence]], and that part of the purpose of mortal life is for men and women to be [[sealing (Mormonism)|sealed]] together, forming bonds that allow them to [[exaltation (Mormonism)|progress eternally]] together in the afterlife. It also teaches that sexual relations within the framework of opposite-sex marriage is healthy, necessary, and ordained of God. In contrast with some orthodox Christian movements, sexuality in the Church's theology is neither a product of [[original sin]] nor a "necessary evil". In accordance with the [[law of chastity]], LDS Church doctrine bars sexual activity outside of heterosexual marriage.
==Chastity== {{Main|Law of chastity}} The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints teaches its members to obey what it calls the [[law of chastity]], which is a code of [[morality]] and [[modesty]]. Under this code, all members are taught to be "morally clean in their thoughts, words, and actions" and to abstain from pornography.<ref name="SbT:Chastity">{{cite book|chapter-url= http://www.lds.org/study/topics/chastity |chapter= Chastity |title= Gospel Study: Study by Topic |work= LDS.org |publisher= [[LDS Church]] |date= }}</ref> Violations of this code include "adultery, being without natural affection, lustfulness, infidelity, incontinence,<ref>Secondary definition: [[Incontinence (philosophy)]]: lacking in moderation or self-control, especially of sexual desire.</ref> filthy communications, impurity, inordinate affection, fornication. They included all sexual relations outside marriage—petting, sex perversion, and preoccupation with sex in one’s thoughts and talking."<ref name="Kimball">{{citation |last= Kimball |first= Spencer W. |url= http://www.lds.org/ensign/1980/11/president-kimball-speaks-out-on-morality |title= Kimball Speaks Out on Morality |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] |date=November 1980 }}</ref>
Though [[celestial marriage]] is the only form of marriage recognized as a [[ordinance (Latter Day Saints)|sacrament]], the church permits sex within government-recognized marital unions, the notable exceptions being [[same-sex marriage]], [[common law marriage]], [[civil union]]s (in jurisdictions where marriage is available), and [[polygamy]]. The church is sensitive about its [[Mormonism and polygamy|historical relationship]] with polygamy, and entry into a polygamous marriage, even where legal, will result in mandatory consideration of [[disciplinary council|church discipline]] and possible [[excommunication]].<ref name = handbookdisciplinemandatory>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Stake Presidents and Bishops]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) §§ 6.7.3, 6.9.3.</ref> Today, the church's teachings allow married couples to decide what is appropriate [[human sexual behavior|sexual behavior]] between themselves.<ref>Some church leaders have taught that [[oral sex]], [[anal sex]], and [[contraception]] are sinful, but there is no official policy prohibiting them.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}</ref> The law of chastity has also been interpreted to include various standards of [[modesty]],<ref name="SbT:Modesty">{{cite book |chapter-url= http://www.lds.org/study/topics/modesty |chapter= Modesty |title= Gospel Study: Study by Topic |work= LDS.org |publisher= [[LDS Church]] |date= }}</ref> which have varied according to [[Norm (sociology)|cultural norms]] of the time. Serious offenses of the law of chastity may result in church discipline, including the possibility of excommunication.<ref name = handbookdisciplinepossible>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Stake Presidents and Bishops]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) §§ 6.7.2.</ref>
[[LGBT]] members of the church are expected to keep the [[law of chastity]].<ref name="hinckley98">{{citation |last= Hinckley |first= Gordon B. |author-link= Gordon B. Hinckley |title= What Are People Asking about Us? |url= http://www.lds.org/ensign/1998/11/what-are-people-asking-about-us |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] |date=November 1998 }}</ref> The church characterizes its church discipline policy as neutral regarding sexual orientation.<ref name=Lattin1997>{{Citation |last= Lattin |first= Don |title= Musings of the Main Mormon: Gordon B. Hinckley, "president, prophet, seer and revelator: of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, sits at the top of one of the world's fastest-growing religions |date= April 13, 1997 |newspaper= [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/1997/04/13/SC36289.DTL |quote= Hinckley: “Now we have gays in the church. Good people. We take no action against such people – provided they don’t become involved in transgression, sexual transgression. If they do, we do with them exactly what we’d do with heterosexuals who transgress. }}</ref> If gay or lesbian members desire to enter into a heterosexual marriage, they are advised that they should first learn to deal with their homosexual feelings; otherwise, they must remain celibate.<ref name="Oaks-Wickman 2007">{{cite interview |first= Dallin H. |last= Oaks |subjectlink= Dallin H. Oaks |first2= Lance B. |last2= Wickman |subjectlink2= Lance B. Wickman |interviewer= LDS Church Public Affairs staffers |title= Same-Gender Attraction |url= http://newsroom.lds.org/official-statement/same-gender-attraction |type=Interview: Transcript |work= Newsroom, LDS Church |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |year= 2007 }}</ref> Gay or lesbian sex, in any form, whether the participants are married or not, is grounds for church discipline.<ref name = handbookdisciplinepossible/> Participation in "repeated homosexual activities (by adults)" results in the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]] making a permanent special annotation to a person's membership record.<ref>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Stake Presidents and Bishops]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) §§ 6.13.3.</ref> In most cases, gay or lesbian sex bars a person, permanently, from serving as a church [[Mormon missionary|missionary]].<ref>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Stake Presidents and Bishops]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) §§ 4.5.2: "A candidate who has participated in homosexual activity during or after the last three teenage years will not normally be considered for missionary service, especially if the person has participated in such activities with several partners or with one partner over an extended period of time. In rare cases the stake president may submit a recommendation that the First Presidency consider an exception if there is strong evidence of genuine repentance and reformation and if the candidate has been free of transgression for a sufficient period of time. This period of repentance should be at least one year and may be as long as three years if the acts occurred several times or over an extended time or if the person was the aggressor."</ref>
==Masturbation== {{Main article|Masturbation and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints}} {{See also|Religious views on masturbation}}

==Kissing== Church leaders have stated that outside of marriage "[[French kiss|passionate kisses]]", defined as "more intense and last[ing] longer than a brief kiss",<ref>{{cite web|title=For the Strength of Youth says not to participate in "passionate kissing." What is that?|url=https://www.lds.org/new-era/2012/07/to-the-point/for-the-strength-of-youth-says-not-to-participate-in-passionate-kissing-what-is-that?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church}}</ref> and "prolonged kisses that involve the tongue and excite the passions" are "off limits".<ref name="Q&A: Questions and Answers">{{cite web|last1=Curtis|first1=Lindsay|title=Q&A: Questions and Answers|url=https://www.lds.org/new-era/1985/11/qa-questions-and-answers/qa-questions-and-answers?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church}}</ref> For example, church president [[Spencer W. Kimball|Spencer Kimball]], called the "soul kiss" an "abomination" that leads to necking, petting, and "illegitimate babies". He further stated that even when dating for a time a kiss should be a "clean, decent, sexless one like the kiss between a mother and son".<ref name="LDS Church">{{cite news|last1=Shumway|first1=Julia|title=Pairing Off: Counsel for Latter-day Saint singles on kissing|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705370608/Pairing-Off-Counsel-for-Latter-day-Saint-singles-on-kissing.html|agency=Deseret News|publisher=LDS Church|date=14 April 2011}}</ref><ref name="lds.org">{{cite web|title=Talking with Your Children about Moral Purity|url=https://www.lds.org/ensign/1986/12/talking-with-your-children-about-moral-purity?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church}}</ref> He also stated that kissing during casual dating is "asking for trouble" and that kisses should not be "handed out like pretzels".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Monson|first1=Bruce|title=Speaking of Kissing|url=https://www.lds.org/new-era/2001/06/speaking-of-kissing?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church}}</ref><ref name="LDS Church"/> Apostle [[Richard G. Scott|Richard Scott]] advised that physical expressions of romantic feelings between unmarried individuals should be kept to "those that are comfortable in the presence of your parents".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Richard|title=Making the Right Choices|url=https://www.lds.org/ensign/1994/11/making-the-right-choices?lang=eng&noLang=true&path=/ensign/1994/11/making-the-right-choices|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church}}</ref>
==Erotic touch== Church leaders have also condemned erotic touching outside of heterosexual marriage using terms like "necking" for general kissing and stroking of areas outside of the breasts, buttocks, or groin region, and "petting"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Featherstone|first1=Vaughn|title=A Self-Inflicted Purging|url=https://www.lds.org/general-conference/1975/04/a-self-inflicted-purging?lang=eng&_r=1|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church}}</ref> for "fondling a member of the opposite sex in areas that are private, personal, and sacred"<ref name="Q&A: Questions and Answers"/> whether under or over clothing. Necking (passionate kissing with intimate touching) has been called an "insidious practice"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kimball|first1=Spencer|title=Speeches of the Year 1953-54: Be Ye Clean|date=4 May 1954|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, Utah|page=6}}</ref> while petting was called "sinful"<ref name="Think, then Act Safely">{{cite web|last1=Petersen|first1=Mark|title=Think, then Act Safely|url=http://scriptures.byu.edu/gettalk.php?ID=865|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU}}</ref> and "an abomination before God".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Critchlow Jr.|first1=William|title=Spelling Repentance with Seven Big R's|url=https://speeches.byu.edu/talks/william-j-critchlow_spelling-repentance-seven-big-rs/|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU}} Statement in the audio recording at around the 19 minute mark</ref><ref name="lds.org"/><ref name="Kimball"/> Despite the policies on extramarital sex and [[making out]], a 2007 survey of over 1,000 BYU students showed that 4% of single women and 3% of single men had participated in oral sex or intercourse while dating. Additionally, 54% of men and 46% of women BYU students reported "making out and intense kissing" while dating.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chadwick|first1=Bruce|last2=Top|first2=Brent|last3=McClendon|first3=Richard|last4=Smith|first4=Lauren|last5=Judd|first5=Mindy|title=A Survey of Dating and Marriage at BYU|journal=BYU Studies Quarterly|date=1 July 2007|volume=46|issue=3|page=11|url=http://scholarsarchive.byu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3861&context=byusq}}</ref>
==Oral sex== In the early 1980s the church explicitly banned oral sex even for married couples<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mackelprang|first1=Romel W|title='And They Shall Be One Flesh': Sexuality and Contemporary Mormonism|journal=Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought|date=March 1992|volume=25|issue=1|pages=60–61|url=https://www.dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V25N01_51.pdf#page=12 |accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Corcoran|first1=Brent|title=Multiply and Replenish Mormon Essays on Sex and Family|date=1994|publisher=Signature Books|location=Salt Lake City|isbn=978-1-56085-050-2|pages=59|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/multiply-and-replenish-02/|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref> as it was considered an "unnatural, impure, or unholy practice" which reflects verbiage for sexual misconduct in the Church Handbook of Instructions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Handbook 2: Administering the Church|url=https://www.lds.org/handbook/handbook-2-administering-the-church/selected-church-policies?lang=eng#214|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref> In a 5 January 1982 [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]] letter to bishops and other local leaders it was explicitly stated that members who participated in any oral sex were barred from the temple unless they "repented and discontinued" this practice.<ref>{{cite web|title=First Presidency letter|url=https://findingaid.lib.byu.edu/viewItem/MSS%20SC%202041|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|quote=First Presidency letter; Dates: 1982 January 5; Photocopy of a typewritten letter signed by Spencer W. Kimball and other members of the First Presidency of the Mormon Church. ... Includes instructions for local leaders to avoid indelicate inquiries into marital relations, as well as an interpretation of oral sex as constituting an unnatural, impure, or unholy practice.}}</ref> A follow-up letter nine months later on 15 October 1982 stated that the First Presidency had received numerous complaints of church leaders inappropriately "delving into private, sensitive matters" and directed leaders to never inquire with "explicit questions" about "intimate matters involving marital relations". The oral sex ban, however, was neither removed, modified, or clarified as the only additional directive to leaders was that "if the member has enough anxiety about the propriety of the conduct to ask about it, the best course would be to discontinue it".
Subsequent discussion of marital sex warned against behaviors that the church considered unnatural, impure, and unholy including [[Spencer J. Condie|Spencer Condie's]] warning that when couples "participate in unholy practices" during their physical intimacy it can become a "disruptive force" in their marriage.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Condie|first1=Spencer|title=Finding Marital Unity through the Scriptures|url=https://www.lds.org/ensign/1986/07/finding-marital-unity-through-the-scriptures?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS church|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref> When discussing physical intimacy a 2003 church manual on marriage quotes church president [[Spencer W. Kimball|Spencer Kimball]] who stated that the idea that "behind the bedroom doors anything goes" is not true nor condoned by the Lord and "if it is unnatural, you just don't do it".<ref>{{cite book|title=Eternal Marriage Student Manual: Intimacy in Marriage|date=2003|publisher=LDS Church|url=https://www.lds.org/manual/eternal-marriage-student-manual/intimacy-in-marriage?lang=eng|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref> Previous to this more public ban, in a private letter dated 17 May 1973, church President [[Harold B. Lee|Harold Lee]] called "oral lovemaking" a "degrading" "perversion" that was "abhorrent in the sight of the Lord".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schoenkopf|first1=Rebecca|title=Mormons Apparently Not Allowed To Do Sex With Their Mouths|url=https://wonkette.com/485389/mormons-apparently-not-allowed-to-do-sex-with-their-mouths|website=wonkette.com|publisher=Commie Girl Industries, Inc|date=28 September 2012|quote=LDS President Harold B. Lee: I was shocked to have you raise the question about ‘oral lovemaking in the genital area among married couples.’ Heaven forbid any such degrading activities which would be abhorrent in the sight of the Lord. For any Latter-day Saint, and particularly those who have been taught in the sacred ordinances of the temple, to engage in any kind of perversions of this sacred God-given gift of procreation, would be sure to bring down the condemnation of the Lord whom we would offend were we to engage in any such practice.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kay|first1=Lorelei|title=From Mormon To Mermaid|date=19 May 2016|publisher=Dog Ear Publishing|isbn=978-1457542930|page=207}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Taylor|first1=Mark A.|title=Sin and Death in Mormon Country: A Latter-day Tragedy|date=April 1986|publisher=Hustler|page=88|url=https://archive.org/stream/LatterDayTragedy/Latter-Day-Tragedy#page/n5/mode/1up|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref> In a popular book sold by the church's bookstore and cowritten by a BYU professor the authors state that oral sex is unworthy and impure for married couples.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brinley|first1=Douglas|last2=Lamb|first2=Stephen|title=Between Husband and Wife: Gospel Perspectives on Marital Intimacy|date=2000|publisher=Covenant Communications|chapter=Drawing the Line|location=American Fork, Utah|isbn=978-1577346098|pages=163–171|chapter-url=https://deseretbook.com/p/between-husband-wife-gospel-perspectives-marital-intimacy-douglas-e-brinley-1654?variant_id=124565-paperback}} [https://books.google.com/books/about/Between_Husband_Wife.html?id=kklNPAAACAAJ Alternate link].</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ingraham|first1=Mike|title=Sex in Zion: A manual for Mormons, written by a Logan native, is leaping off the shelves|url=https://news.hjnews.com/sex-in-zion-a-manual-for-mormons-written-by-a/article_48b165c6-75e6-558e-a765-1580b21962f8.html|work=The Herald Journal|date=20 July 2000|quote=The index is not so coy. 'Oral sex, 163-71' it says. That is the chapter 'Drawing the Line.' 'We wrestled with that,' Brinley says. The authors evidently decided to take their cue from President Boyd K. Packer who told BYU students 'If something unworthy has become part of your relationship, don't ever do it again! Now what exactly do I mean by that? You know what I mean by that.'}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fulton|first1=Ben|title=The Missionary Position: An LDS guide joins the fray of sexy religious books|url=https://www.cityweekly.net/utah/the-missionary-position/Content?oid=2129212|work=Salt Lake City Weekly|date=11 June 2007|quote=Then there’s a topic so sensitive it dare not speak its name, except to those curious enough to look it up in the index. ... Most Mormons already consider the practice impure anyway, because it’s practiced by gays, lesbians and prostitutes. Besides, Brinley’s confident that readers know what the chapter’s discussing by its tone alone. 'When we talk about sexual acts that are unworthy and unnatural, people know what we’re talking about. Kristin Hodson: No, except in myths and urban legends. Alisha Worthington: And there could be some bishops who you go in and ask who are like, “Oh, no.” Again, it’s who you get. Let’s not give other fallible humans the authority to make decisions regarding our most private, personal pleasure.}}</ref>

==Birth control and abortion== {{See also|Religion and birth control|Christian views on contraception|Abortion and Christianity|Religion and abortion}} [[File:Kondom.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Church leaders have changed from condemning contraception even for married couples to currently leaving family planning decisions to each couple.]]
In the past the use of family planning [[birth control]] methods including artificial contraception was explicitly condemned by LDS church leaders. Beginning in July 1916 apostles were quoted stating that birth control was a "pernicious doctrine" and that "limiting the number of children in a family...is sinful".<ref>{{cite journal|title=Birth Control|journal=Relief Society Magazine|date=July 1916|volume=3|issue=7|pages=364, 368|url=https://archive.org/stream/reliefsocietymag03reli#page/n403/mode/2up/search/birth+control|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref><ref name="Dialogue">{{cite journal|last1=Bush Jr.|first1=Lester E.|title=Birth Control Among the Mormons: An Introduction to an Insistent Question|journal=Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought|date=Fall 1976|volume=10|issue=2|page=21|url=https://dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V10N02_14.pdf|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> The first time that any approval of a non-abstinence fertility control method was publicly expressed occurred in a 1942 [[Improvement Era]] article in which Apostle [[John A. Widtsoe|John Widtsoe]] mentioned the [[Calendar-based contraceptive methods|rhythm method]] as an acceptable means of spacing children.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bush|first1=Lester E.|title=Multiply and Replenish: Mormon Essays on Sex and Family|date=1994|publisher=Signature Books|location=Salt Lake City|isbn=978-1-56085-050-2|pages=187–188|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/multiply-and-replenish-09/|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> In his influential 1956 treatise ''Doctrines of Salvation'', then apostle [[Joseph Fielding Smith]] called birth control a wickedness which leads to damnation and caused the downfall of nations. He further stated that an LDS couple that deliberately prevents themselves from having more children after their second or third child is guilty of iniquity which must be punished.<ref>{{Citation | editor1-last= McConkie | editor1-first= Bruce R. | editor1-link= Bruce R. McConkie | last= Smith | first= Joseph Fielding | author-link= Joseph Fielding Smith | title= Doctrines of Salvation: Sermons and Writings of Joseph Fielding Smith | volume= 2 | url= https://archive.org/stream/JFSDoctrinesOfSalvation/JFSDoctrinesofSalvationv1-3#page/n272/mode/1up/search/birth+control+is+wickedness | year= 1954–56 | pages= 273–274 | publisher= Bookcraft |quote=Birth control is wickedness. The abuse of this holy covenant [to be fruitful and multiply] has been the primary cause for the downfall of nations. ... When a man and a woman are married and they agree, or covenant, to limit their offspring to two or three, and practice devices to accomplish this purpose, they are guilty of iniquity which eventually must be punished. Unfortunately this evil doctrine is being taught as a virtue by many people who consider themselves cultured and highly educated. It has even crept in among members of the Church and has been advocated in some of the classes within the Church. It should be understood definitely that this kind of doctrine is not only not advocated by the authorities of the Church, but also is condemned by them as wickedness in the sight of the Lord. ... Possibly no greater sin could be committed by the people who have embraced this gospel than to prevent or to destroy life in the manner indicated. ... Birth control leads to damnation.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Teachings Concerning Birth Control and Family Size: First Presidency Statements and Church Handbook of Instructions|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070115134700/http://emp.byui.edu/SATTERFIELDB/PDF/Quotes/Birth%20Control%20Family%20Size.pdf|archive-date=15 January 2007|date=May 2004|page=3|url=http://emp.byui.edu/SATTERFIELDB/Quotes/Birth%20Control%20Family%20Size.htm|website=emp.byui.edu|publisher=BYU-Idaho Employee Website|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> The 1958 edition of McConkie's popular book [[Mormon Doctrine (book)|Mormon Doctrine]] stated that all those using condoms or other artificial contraception are "in rebellion against God and are guilty of gross wickedness."<ref name="Changes">{{cite book|last1=Dye|first1=David A.|title=Changes in Mormon Doctrine: A Comparison of the 1958 & 1966 versions of Mormon Doctrine by Bruce R. McConkie|date=2007|publisher=Lulu Press|isbn=9781257255009}}</ref>{{rp|12}} The [[Church Educational System Honor Code|BYU Honor Code]] in 1968 stated that "the Church does not approve of any form of birth control."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilkinon|first1=Ernest L.|title=Presidential Files, Memorandum: Conference Held with First Presidency|date=18 August 1967|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, UT, BYU HBLL Special Collections UA 1000 Box 271 Folder 22|page=2|url=http://files.lib.byu.edu/ead/XML/UA1000.xml|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref> In 1969 the first and only First Presidency statement on birth control was released reemphasizing that it was "contrary to the teachings of the Church artificially to curtail or prevent the birth of children", though, for the first time there was a clarification that men should be considerate to "conserve" the "health and strength" of their wives when planning families since they carry the "greater responsibility" for bearing and rearing children.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bush Jr.|first1=Lester E.|title=Birth Control Among the Mormons: An Introduction to an Insistent Question|journal=Dialogue: A Journal of Mormon Thought|date=Fall 1976|volume=10|issue=2|page=27|url=https://dialoguejournal.com/wp-content/uploads/sbi/articles/Dialogue_V10N02_14.pdf|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref>
Other discussions of the topic include those by [[Ezra Taft Benson|Ezra Benson]] who became a church president. He stated that those that advocate for birth control perpetuate types of government that cause famine,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Benson |first1=Ezra |title=To the Humble Followers of Christ |journal=The Improvement Era |date=June 1969 |volume=72 |issue=6 |page=44 |url=https://archive.org/stream/improvementera7206unse#page/n45/mode/1up}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Ezra |first1=Benson |title=To the Humble Followers of Christ |url=http://scriptures.byu.edu/#:t685:g8b |website=byu.edu |publisher=Brigham Young University| quote=The world teaches birth control. Kimball|Spencer Kimball]] stating that the church does not "condone nor approve of" measures of contraception which greatly "limit the family".<ref>{{cite web|title=Eternal Marriage Student Manual: Birth Control|url=https://www.lds.org/manual/eternal-marriage-student-manual/birth-control?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref>
The current church stance is that "decisions about birth control and the consequences of those decisions rest solely with each married couple" and that they should consider "the physical and mental health of the mother and father and their capacity to provide the basic necessities of life for their children" when planning a family.<ref>{{cite web|title=Birth Control|url=https://www.lds.org/topics/birth-control?lang=eng&old=true|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> However, in teaching children about sexual morals and birth control, Mormons parents have ranked among the lowest in comfort discussing these topics with their children among US parents of all religious affiliations.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Regnerus|first1=Mark D.|title=Forbidden Fruit: Sex and Religion in the Lives of American Teenagers|date=19 August 2009|publisher=Oxford University Press Inc.|isbn=9780195395853|page=64|edition=2009 reprint|url=https://books.google.com/?id=1oC1XFaXSysC&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2 July 2017}}</ref> In discussing another method of family planning the church "strongly discourages" surgical sterilization like [[vasectomy|vasectomies]] and [[tubal ligation]] and only allows it for serious medical conditions after discussing it with a bishop.<ref>{{cite web|title=Handbook 2: Administering the Church|url=https://www.lds.org/handbook/handbook-2-administering-the-church/selected-church-policies/21.4?lang=eng&_r=1#214|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> The LDS Church opposes elective [[abortion]] "for personal or social convenience"<ref name = ReferenceA/> but states that abortion could be an acceptable option in cases of rape, incest, danger to the health or life of the mother, or where the fetus has been diagnosed with "severe defects that will not allow the baby to survive beyond birth."<ref name="ReferenceA">[https://lds.org/handbook/handbook-2-administering-the-church/selected-church-policies?lang=eng#21.4.4 ''Handbook 2: Administering the Church''] (2010).</ref>
==Marriage== {{See also|Marriage in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|Plural marriage|Celestial marriage|Sealing (Latter Day Saints)}} [[File:Phil and Marlene.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A couple following their marriage in the [[Manti Utah Temple]]]]
From the 1830s, [[marriage]] has been a central and distinctive component of Mormon theology. Mormon teachings on marriage begins with the belief that, if performed by a person who has the requisite [[priesthood (Latter Day Saints)|priesthood authority]], a marriage may continue in the [[afterlife]]. Such a marriage is called a "[[celestial marriage]]"<ref>In the 19th century, the term "celestial marriage" was used interchangeably with the term "[[plural marriage]]". Some early Mormons (and present-day [[Mormon fundamentalism|Mormon fundamentalists]]) considered polygamy to be a requirement for [[Exaltation (Latter Day Saints)|exaltation]].</ref> or a "temple marriage",<ref>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Bishops and Stake Presidents]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) § 3.5.1.</ref> and is a particular instance of a "[[sealing (Latter Day Saints)|sealing]]" which binds people together in the afterlife. Celestial marriage is considered to be a requirement for entry into the highest "degree" of the [[celestial kingdom]] (the highest degree of [[heaven]] in Latter Day Saint theology), and is thought to allow the participants to continue to have spirit children in the afterlife and [[exaltation (Latter Day Saints)|become gods]]. According to Mormon belief, the continuance of a celestial marriage in the afterlife is contingent upon the couple remaining righteous. In rare cases, a couple's exaltation may be "made sure" through the ritual of the [[second anointing]].
In the 1800s, the practice of celestial marriage included [[plural marriage]], a form of [[polygamy]]. According to a consensus of historians, the practice of plural marriage was taught by [[Joseph Smith]], the founder of the [[Latter Day Saint movement]], and after Smith's death was formally acknowledged in 1852 by [[Brigham Young]], leader of the LDS Church. The practice became famous during the 19th century when it was opposed and outlawed by the United States federal government, resulting in an intense legal conflict, which culminated in LDS Church [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|president]] [[Wilford Woodruff]] issuing the [[1890 Manifesto]], which officially discontinued the creation of new plural marriages in [[Temple (LDS Church)|church temples]].<ref>Woodruff's declaration was formally [[Common consent (Mormonism)|accepted]] by the membership in a church [[general Conference (LDS Church)|general conference]] on October 6, 1890.</ref> Nevertheless, unofficial plural marriages continued within the LDS Church after 1890 for some years, often in [[Mexico]]. In 1904, the church issued a [[Second Manifesto]], which discontinued the official practice worldwide and established excommunication as a possible penalty for violators. These manifestos did not automatically divorce existing plural unions, however, and some couples in the LDS Church continued to live together as plural families well into the 20th century, with the final polygamous marriage in the LDS Church ending in 1954 when one of Edward Eyring's two wives died.
The LDS Church now embraces [[monogamy]] and the [[nuclear family]]. Members who are found entering into or solemnizing polygamous marriages or associating with polygamous groups are now subject to church discipline and possible excommunication.<ref name = handbookdisciplinemandatory/> Beginning in the late-20th century, the LDS Church began supporting political and legal measures to limit legal marriage to a union of one man and one woman.
The LDS Church does, however, continue to recognize some theological aspects of its polygamy doctrine. Although both men and women may enter a celestial marriage with only one partner at a time, a man may be sealed to more than one woman. If his first wife dies, he may enter another celestial marriage, and be sealed to both his living wife and deceased wife or wives. A woman, however, may only be sealed to one man during her lifetime.<ref>The LDS Church has clarified that a woman may also be sealed to more than one man. A woman, however, may not be sealed to more than one man while she is alive. She may only be sealed to subsequent partners after she has died: ''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Bishops and Stake Presidents]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) § 3.6.1. Church leaders have not clarified if women in such circumstances will live in a polyandrous relationship in the afterlife. It should be noted, however, that proxy sealings, like proxy baptisms, are merely offered to the person in the afterlife, indicating that the purpose may be to allow the woman to choose the man she wishes to be sealed to.</ref> This leaves room to believe that all these marriages will be valid in the eternities and the husband and all his sealed wives will live together in the afterlife as a polygamous family. In the 1950s, one influential church leader wrote that plural marriage would "obviously" be reinstituted after the [[Second Coming]] of Jesus.<ref>[[Bruce R. McConkie]], ''[[Mormon Doctrine (book)|Mormon Doctrine]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: Bookcraft, 1958) s.v. "Plural marriage": "Obviously the holy practice will commence again after the Second Coming of the Son of Man and the ushering in of the Millennium."</ref>
While not accorded the theological significance of a celestial marriage, the LDS Church does recognize civil marriages or marriages performed within other religious traditions. In the 1870s, a prominent Mormon writer wrote that Mormons considered such a marriage to be "no marriage at all."<ref>{{harvtxt|Penrose|1871|p=4}}</ref> Today, however, non-celestial marriages are respected and recognized as valid by the church, but such marriages must be legal according to the government where the marriage is performed, and must not be a [[same-sex marriage]], polygamous marriage, [[common law marriage]], or other type of non-ceremonial marriages in non–[[common law]] countries. Moreover, such marriages are thought to last only for the mortal life, and not into the next. In countries where the church's celestial marriages are not recognized by the government, the church requires that it be preceded by a civil marriage.<ref>''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook 1: Bishops and Stake Presidents]]'' (Salt Lake City, Utah: LDS Church, 2010) § 3.6.1.</ref>
In the United States, the LDS Church has expressed support for a constitutional ban on same-sex and polygamous marriage and has stated that it "favors measures that define marriage as the union of a man and a woman and that do not confer legal status on any other sexual relationship."<ref name=Statement>{{Citation |last1= Hinckley |first1= Gordon B. |author1-link= Gordon B. Hinckley |last2= Monson |first2= Thomas S. |author2-link= Thomas S. Monson |last3= Faust |first3= James E. |author3-link= James E. Faust |title= First Presidency Statement on Same-Gender Marriage |publisher= LDS Church |place= Salt Lake City, Utah |date= October 20, 2004 |url= http://newsroom.lds.org/article/first-presidency-statement-on-same-gender-marriage }}.</ref> The church's position is that government recognition of such rights will "undermine the divinely created institution of the family".<ref name=Statement />
==Sexual orientation== {{Main|Homosexuality and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints}} {{See also|Christianity and sexual orientation|Homosexuality and religion|Religion and LGBT people}} [[File:SLC Temple Rainbow Flag.jpg|thumb|right|125px|A gay pride flag in front of the [[Salt Lake Temple|SLC temple]].]] The church recognizes and officially welcomes gays and lesbians as members<ref name=Why>{{Citation |publisher= ''Ensign'' |first= Gordon B. |last= Hinckley |title= Why We Do Some of the Things We Do |date=Nov 1999 |url= http://www.lds.org/ensign/1999/11/why-we-do-some-of-the-things-we-do |quote= Our hearts reach out to those who refer to themselves as gays and lesbians. We love and honor them as sons and daughters of God. They are welcome in the Church. }}</ref> under condition that they attempt to live the church's moral code. The church teaches that homosexual feelings, as distinct from behavior, may sometimes seem to be inborn,<ref name="oaks95">{{citation|first= Dallin H. |last= Oaks |author-link= Dallin H. Oaks |url= http://www.lds.org/ensign/1995/10/same-gender-attraction |title= Same-Gender Attraction |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] |date=October 1995 |accessdate= 2011-08-17}}</ref> and that although these feelings are sometimes unwanted, they can and should be controlled.<ref name="Oaks-Wickman 2007" /> The church's [[law of chastity]] forbids homosexual sex in all contexts. Consistently breaking the law of chastity may result in [[excommunication]]. Nevertheless, Latter-day Saints who identify themselves as gay or lesbian may remain in good standing in the church, without ramification, if they abstain from homosexual relations.<ref name="hinckley98" /><ref name="Oaks-Wickman 2007" />
In addition to opposing gay and lesbian sex, the LDS Church also opposes and campaigns against the extension of marital rights to gay and lesbian families that would, in its opinion, undermine the tradition of heterosexual monogamous marriage.<ref name=Statement /> Since the 1990s, the issue of [[same-sex marriage]] has been one of the church’s foremost political concerns. [[File:Mormons and Gays Website Header.jpg|thumb|left|This header was at the top of the LDS church's first official website on homosexuality from December 2012 until an update in October 2016.]] In 2008, the church participated in a campaign in support of [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|California Proposition 8]], which proposed limiting the definition of marriage to a union of one man and one woman. This mobilized many of its members to donate time and money towards the initiative. The political organization [[ProtectMarriage.com]], the official proponents of Proposition 8, estimate that about half the donations they received came from Mormon sources, and that "eighty to ninety percent" of the early volunteers going door-to-door were members of the LDS Church.<ref>{{Citation |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/15/us/politics/15marriage.html?_r=2&pagewanted=1&hp&oref=slogin |title= Mormons Tipped Scale in Ban on Gay Marriage |date= 2008-11-14 |accessdate= 2008-12-24 |newspaper= The New York Times |first1= Jesse |last1= McKinley |first2= Kirk |last2= Johnson }}</ref> The church was criticized for its involvement by non-members and by some of its members, and in 2010, [[general authority]] [[Marlin K. Jensen]] personally apologized to church members in California for the church's role.<ref>[[Joanna Brooks]], [http://religiondispatches.org/mormon-leader-im-sorry-for-hurtful-legacy-of-prop-8/ "Mormon Leader: ‘I’m Sorry’ For Hurtful Legacy of Prop. 8"], ''[[Religion Dispatches]]'', 2010-09-28: "According to attendee [[Carol Lynn Pearson]], a Mormon author and longtime advocate of LGBT concerns, Elder Jensen said, 'To the full extent of my capacity, I say that I am sorry... I know that many very good people have been deeply hurt, and I know that the Lord expects better of us.'"</ref> In December 2012 a landmark website "Mormons and Gays" was launched dedicated to the topic of homosexuality.
==Gender==
{{See also|Gender minorities and the LDS church|Gender|Gender and religion|Women in Christianity|Women and religion|Complementarianism|Christianity and transgender|Transgender people and religion}}
Gender identity and roles play an important part in Mormon theology which teaches a strict binary of spiritual gender as literal offspring of divine parents.<ref name="Proclamation">{{citation |url= http://www.lds.org/family/proclamation |title= The Family: A Proclamation to the World |year= 1995 |publisher= LDS Church }}</ref><ref name="Essential">{{citation |first= David A. |last= Bednar |author-link= David A. Bednar |title= Marriage Is Essential to His Eternal Plan |url= //www.lds.org/ensign/2006/06/marriage-is-essential-to-his-eternal-plan |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] |date=June 2006 |page= 83 }}</ref> Part of Sunday Church meetings are currently divided by biological sex,<ref>{{cite book|title=Handbook 2: Administering the Church|date=2010|publisher=LDS Church|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|section=18. Meetings in the Church|url=https://lds.org/handbook/handbook-2-administering-the-church/meetings-in-the-church?lang=eng|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918212635/https://lds.org/handbook/handbook-2-administering-the-church/meetings-in-the-church?lang=eng|archivedate=2017-09-18|df=}}</ref> and for most of the 1800s church presidents [[Joseph Smith]] and [[Brigham Young]] had men, women, and children sit separately for all Sunday meetings.<ref name="Dynamics">{{cite book|last1=Quinn|first1=D. Michael|title=Same-Sex Dynamics among Nineteenth-Century Americans|date=1996|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0252022050|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UXVj398JvnsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>{{rp|410,413–414}} Expressions and identities for [[Human sexuality|sexuality]] and [[gender]] are "separate, but related" aspects of a person<ref>{{cite web|title=Resolution on Gender and Sexual Orientation Diversity in Children and Adolescents in Schools|url=http://www.apa.org/about/policy/orientation-diversity.aspx|website=American Psychological Association|publisher=APA|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> and stem from similar biological origins.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bao|first1=Ai-Min|last2=Swaab|first2=Dick F.|title=Sexual differentiation of the human brain: Relation to gender identity, sexual orientation and neuropsychiatric disorders|journal=Frontiers in Neuroendocrinology|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0091302211000252|date=April 2011|volume=32|issue=2|pages=214–226|accessdate=9 December 2016|doi=10.1016/j.yfrne.2011.02.007|pmid=21334362}}</ref> As far as gender minorities, Church leaders have stated that they have unfinished business<ref name="slate.com">{{cite news|last1=Petrey|first1=Taylor G.|title=A Mormon Leader Signals New Openness on Transgender Issues. This Could Be Huge.|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/outward/2015/02/13/mormons_and_transgender_elder_dallin_h_oaks_says_the_lds_church_is_open.html|accessdate=21 November 2016|agency=Slate|date=13 February 2015}}</ref> in teaching on the difficult and sensitive topic of transgender individuals.<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|last1=Levin|first1=Sam|title=Transgender and Mormon: keeping the faith while asking the church to change|journal=The Guardian|date=28 March 2016|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/28/transgender-mormon-lgbt-rights-emmett-claren|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=Samantha|title=Mormon Man Risks Excommunication By Sharing His Transition|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/16/mormon-man-risks-excommunication-by-sharing-his-transition.html|accessdate=9 December 2016|agency=The Daily Beast|date=15 March 2016}}</ref> In the past, church president [[Joseph Fielding Smith]], stated that he believed that those who did not reach the celestial kingdom in the afterlife would be "neither man nor woman, merely immortal beings".<ref name="Doctrines">{{Citation | editor1-last= McConkie | editor1-first= Bruce R. | editor1-link= Bruce R. McConkie | last= Smith | first= Joseph Fielding | author-link= Joseph Fielding Smith | title= Doctrines of Salvation: Sermons and Writings of Joseph Fielding Smith | volume= 2 | url= https://archive.org/stream/JFSDoctrinesOfSalvation/JFSDoctrinesofSalvationv1-3#page/n395/mode/1up | year= 1954–56 | page= 396 | publisher= Bookcraft |quote= I take it that men and women will, in [the terrestrial and telestial] kingdoms, be just what the so-called Christian world expects us all to be—neither man nor woman, merely immortal beings having received the resurrection.}}</ref>
Within the church, there have also been a number of unofficial statements regarding gender. For example, "Strengthening Our Families: An In-Depth Look at the Proclamation on the Family"<ref>{{harvnb|Dollahite|2000}}</ref> (a book compiled by the School of Family Life at the church-owned [[Brigham Young University]]) states, "Although we do not fully understand the eternal nature of gender, we should acknowledge its meaning and purpose, and humbly seek to understand and appreciate the nature of divine gender distinctions in God's plan for His children."<ref>{{harvnb|Dollahite|2000|page=76}}</ref> The book also states: <blockquote>God created us male and female. This is not a mistake or a variety of genetic or hormonal chance. What we call gender is an essential characteristic of our existence prior to our birth. Gender is part of our eternal identity and essential to our eternal progression. Although we may not know all the reasons why this is so, we do know some of the reasons why gender is essential to our eternal progression. To achieve our exaltation, an eternal marriage between a man and a woman is necessary. ...The sexual union between a married man and woman is, among other things, the means God has ordained to bring His spirit children into mortality, which is an essential step in the plan of salvation.<ref>{{harvnb|Dollahite|2000|page=223}}</ref></blockquote> [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|Apostle]] [[David A. Bednar]] stated: "[Gender] in large measure defines who we are, why we are here upon the earth, and what we are to do and become. For divine purposes, male and female spirits are different, distinctive, and complementary. ...The unique combination of spiritual, physical, mental, and emotional capacities of both males and females were needed to implement the plan of happiness".<ref name="Essential" /> Apostle [[M. Russell Ballard]] taught, "The premortal and mortal natures of men and women were specified by God Himself. ...[Sometimes women] ask: 'Is a woman's value dependent exclusively upon her role as a wife and mother?' The answer is simple and obvious: No. ...Every righteous man and woman has a significant role to play in the onward march of the kingdom of God."<ref>{{citation |first= M. Russell |last= Ballard |author-link= M. Russell Ballard |title= Women of Righteousness |url= //www.lds.org/ensign/2002/04/women-of-righteousness |journal= [[Ensign (LDS magazine)|Ensign]] |date=April 2002 |pages= 66–69 }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Latter-day Saints}} * [[Christian views on contraception#Mormonism|Christian views on contraception: Mormonism]] * [[Christianity and abortion#Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|Christianity and abortion: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]

'''German Sikhs''' are a religious minority in [[Germany]]. Many German [[Sikhs]] have their roots from the [[Punjab]] region in north [[India]]. They number between 15,000 to 21,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://remid.de/info_zahlen/verschiedene/|title=Mitgliederzahlen: Sonstige - REMID - Religionswissenschaftlicher Medien- und Informationsdienst e.V.|website=remid.de|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref> Germany had the third highest Sikh population in Europe after [[United Kingdom]] and [[Italy]].
In the early 21st century, also native Germans have adopted the Sikh Faith. Frankfurt, is also known to the Sikhs, as Mini Punjab, because of a great Sikh Population, residing there. Information about Sikhism and an updated list of Gurudwaras in Germany, Austria and Switzerland you can find on the DISR German information center for Sikh Religion, Sikh History and Culture - DISR website: https://deutsches-informationszentrum-sikhreligion.de or under https://www.sikh-religion.de
==Gurdwaras==

{{Infobox organization |name = Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia |image = SRIA.png |size = 200px |caption = The logo of the Societas Rosicruciana, featuring a [[pentagram]] inside a red cross. |motto = |formation = 1865 |extinction = |headquarters = Stanfield Hall,
88 High Street,
[[Hampstead]],
[[London]],
NW3 1RE | location = [[England and Wales]] |type = [[Freemasonry]]
[[Rosicrucianism]] | main_organ = ''The Rosicrucian'' | parent_organization = [[United Grand Lodge of England]] | successor = [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]] | leader_title = Supreme Magus | leader_name = [[Robert Wentworth Little]] (1869-1878)
[[John Paternoster]]
(2006-present) |website = [https://www.sria.info/ sria.info] }} {{Freemasonry}} '''Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia''' (Rosicrucian Society of England) is a [[Freemasonry|Masonic]] [[esoteric Christianity|esoteric Christian]] order formed by [[Robert Wentworth Little]] in 1865,King 1989, page 28J. Gordon Melton, page 179 although some sources acknowledge the date to be 1866-67.C.M., The Rosicrucians, page 109[http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/biography/esoterica/little_r/little_r.html R.W. Littles Biography] at the Grand Lodge of British Columbia and Yukon Members are confirmed from the ranks of subscribing [[Master Mason]]s of a [[Grand Lodge]] in amity with [[United Grand Lodge of England]]. The structure and grade of this order, as [[A. E. Waite]] suggests, were derived from the 18th-century German [[Order of the Golden and Rosy Cross]]. It later became the same grade system used for the [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn|Golden Dawn]].[http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/aqc/waite/waite.html The masonic career of A.E. Waite] by Bro. R. A. Gilbert ==History== The society claims to be inspired by the original [[Rosicrucian]] Brotherhood but does not allege a provable link thereto. It bases its teachings on those found in the ''Fama'' and ''Confessio Fraternitas'' published in the early 17th century in Germany along with other similar publications from the same time. The society was founded in 1867, derived from a pre-existing Rosicrucian order in Scotland (which bore no relation to similarly named the Societas Rosicruciana in Scotia, which was a later creation), following the admission of William James Hughan and [[Robert Wentworth Little]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} Little was a clerk and cashier of the General Secretary of the [[United Grand Lodge of England]], [[William Henry White]]. These Fratres were advanced quickly in Scotland and granted a warrant to form a Society in England. The formation meeting took place on 1 June 1867 in Aldermanbury, London with Frater Little elected Master Magus, the title of "Supreme Magus" not being invented until some years later. They produced a journal, called ''The Rosicrucian'', which was co-edited by [[William Robert Woodman]]. ==Membership requirements== The society requires all aspirants for membership to declare a belief in the fundamental principles of the [[Trinitarianism|Trinitarian]] Christian faith and offers assistance to all its members in working out the great problems of nature and science. ==Structure and governance== The Order is subdivided into: ===1st Order=== Members of the 1st Order(''Fratres'') meet in a College which is equivalent to a Freemasons Lodge. A College is empowered to confer the first four degrees of the society which are known as Grades. A minimum of six months must elapse between the receipt of grades. However, the emphasis in the work of the society is learning, therefore every member is encouraged to deliver a paper of their own work on some topic of interest in open college. *Grade I - Zelator *Grade II - Theoricus *Grade III - Practicus *Grade IV - Philosophus ===2nd Order=== This is equivalent to a Masonic Provincial Grand Lodge headed by a Chief Adept and his deputy (Suffragan) who have jurisdiction over all first order Colleges within the Province. The Chief Adept is empowered to confer three further Grades at this level to deserving ''Fratres'' of Grade IV who have been a member of the Society for a minimum of four years. *Grade V - Adeptus Minor *Grade VI - Adeptus Major *Grade VII - Adeptus Exemptus A minimum of one year must elapse between the receipt of grades at this level. A member can only serve as the Celebrant (Master) of a College of the First Order after receiving the Grade of Adeptus Exemptus. ===3rd Order=== This is equivalent to a Grand Lodge headed by a Supreme Magus, Senior Substitute Magus and Junior Substitute Magus. Members of the second order who have given service to the society and been selected by the Supreme Magus for such advancement may be awarded a further two Grades. *Grade VIII - Magister *Grade IX - Magus ==Influences== [[File:Structure of Masonic appendant bodies in England and Wales.jpg|thumb|The position of the Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia among the Masonic appendant bodies in England and Wales]] In 1888, three members of SRIA formed the [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]], which removed the restriction on membership, allowing non-Christians, non-Freemasons, and women to join. A great deal of the SRIA structure survived in the new order, which went on to greatly influence the modern occult revival in the 20th century. ==Supreme Magus== {{fact|date=October 2017}} * [[Robert Wentworth Little]] (1869-1878) * [[William Robert Woodman]] (1878-1891) * [[William Wynn Westcott]] (1891-1925) * [[W. J. Songhurst]] (1925-39) * [[Frank M. Rickard]] (1939-56) * [[W. R. Semken]] (1956-69) * [[Edward Varley Kayley]] (1969-74) * [[Donald Penrose]] (1974-79) * [[Norman C. Stamford]] (1979-82) * [[Alan G. Davies]] (1982-94) * [[Ronald E. Rowland]] (1994-2002) * [[Andrew B. Stevenson]] (2002-06) * [[John Paternoster]] (2006-present) ==Known members== *[[William Robert Woodman]] *[[William Wynn Westcott]] *[[Kenneth R. H. Mackenzie]] *[[Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mathers|Samuel Liddell "MacGregor" Mathers]] *[[Arthur Edward Waite]] *[[John Yarker]] *[[Robert Felkin]] *[[Frederick Bligh Bond]] ==Modern times== The Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia has led to a number of similar organisations in different countries such as Scotland, Canada, and two in America.Morrisson, page 18 ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|last=King|first=Francis X.|authorlink=Francis X. King|title=Modern Ritual Magic: The Rise of Western Occultism|edition=2nd|publisher=|year=|isbn=}} * {{cite book|last=McIntosh|first=Christopher|authorlink=|title=The Rosicrucians|edition=|publisher=|year=|isbn=}} * {{cite book|last=Melton|first=Gordon J.|authorlink=|title=The Encyclopedia of American Religions|edition=|publisher=|year=|isbn=}} * {{cite book|last=Morrisson|first=Mark S.|authorlink=|title=Modern Alchemy|edition=|publisher=|year=|isbn=}} ==External links== *[http://www.sria.info/ Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia] - Official Website. *[http://www.themasonictrowel.com/Articles/General/other_files/the_seven_steps_of_wisdom_sria.htm Seven Steps of Wisdom]: an online course of introduction to the principles of the SRIA. *[http://www.bishopwilkins.co.uk/ Bishop Wilkins SRIA College] An SRIA college with papers, Rosicrucian texts and information about the Society. {{s-start}} {{S-bef|before=[[Craft Freemasonry]]}} {{S-ttl|title=Societas Rosicruciana in Anglia}} {{S-aft|after=[[Royal Order of Eri]]}} {{S-end}} {{Magic and Witchcraft in the British Isles}} {{UGLE}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Societas Rosicruciana In Anglia}} [[Category:Hermeticism]] [[Category:Masonic organizations]] [[Category:Rosicrucianism]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox holiday |type = Hindu |longtype = Religious, folk |image = Sri Vaikuntha Ekadashi ISKCON Bangalore.jpg |caption = Vaikuntha Ekadashi |official_name = Vaikuntha Ekadashi |nickname = |observedby = [[Hindu]]s |begins = |ends = |duration = 1 day |date = |date2017= 8 January & 29 December <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://calendar-panchang.com/2017-marathi-calendar-panchang/1/|title=2017 Marathi Calendar Panchang|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref> |frequency=annual |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = }}
'''Vaikunta Ekadashi''' is the [[Shukla paksha|Shukla Paksha]] [[Ekadashi]] that occurs during the [[Dhanu (month)|Dhanu]] month in the [[Hindu calendar]] (corresponding to late December - January in [[Gregorian calendar|English calendar]]).<ref>J. Gordon Melton Religious Celebrations: An Encyclopedia of Holidays, Festivals, ... - Volume 2 - - 2011 Page 895 "Vaikuntha Ekadashi - Vaikuntha Ekadashi is the name given to the two fast days on the 11th day of the two halves of the month of Magha (December and January on the Common Era calendar) for Vaishnava Hindus."</ref>
The [[Vaishnavism|Vaishnava]] (Worship of [[Vishnu]]) sect believes that ‘Vaikunta Dwaram’ or ‘the gate to the Lord's Inner Sanctum’ is opened on this day. The Margashirsha Shukla Paksha Ekadashi in the Lunar calendar is known as a 'Mokshada Ekadashi.' Special prayers, ''yagnas'', discourses and speeches are arranged at Vishnu temples across the world on this auspicious day. The [[Shaivism|Shaiva]] sect observes the day as ''Trikoti Ekadashi,'' a religious observance where all the deities in the Hindu pantheon pay obeisance to Lord [[Shiva|Sri Shiva]] at once.
==Legend== {{Hindu philosophy}} According to the Vishnu Purana, [[fasting]] on Vaikuntha Ekadashi is equivalent to fasting on the remaining 23 Ekadashis of the (Hindu) year.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ssvt.org/Festivals/VaikundaEkadasi.pdf | title=Vaikuntha Ekadashi | accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref> However, according to Vaishnava tradition fasting is mandatory on all Ekadashi of both [[Shukla paksha]] and [[Krishna paksha]]. Fasting on Ekadashi is considered holier than any other religious observation.
Vishnu opened the gate of Vaikuntham (his abode) for two demons in spite of their being against him. They also asked for the boon that whoever listens to their story and sees the image of Vishnu coming out of the door (called Dwar), called Vaikunth Dwar, will reach Vaikunth as well. Temples all over India make a door kind of structure on this day for devotees to walk through.
According to Padma Purana, the female energy of Vishnu slayed the demon Muran and protects the 'Devas'. This happened on the eleventh day of lunar month during the sun's journey in the Dhanurrashi or Dhanu Rashi. Impressed by the act, Vishnu names her as 'Ekadashi' and gives her the boon that those who worship 'Ekadashi' on the day of her victory over Muran would reach 'Vaikunth' (His abode).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/mp/2003/12/29/stories/2003122901450100.htm | title=Vaikuntha Ekadasi | publisher=[[The Hindu]] | date=2003-12-29 | accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref>
Vaikuntha Ekadashi is one of the important and auspicious days for Hindus. It is dedicated to Vishnu. It occurs in the Hindu calendar, in the month of Margashirsha (between December and January). When observed, it bestows liberation from the cycle of birth and death.
==Significance== The significance of Vaikuntha Ekadashi is mentioned in the ''Padma Purana''. The legend says that the Devas, unable to bear the tyranny of 'Muran' - a demon, approached Shiva, who directed them to Vishnu. A battle ensued between Vishnu and the demon and Vishnu realized that a new weapon was needed to slay Muran. In order to take rest and create a new weapon, Vishnu retired to a cave for the goddess named [[Haimavati]] in Bhadrikashrama. When Muran tried to slay Vishnu, who was sleeping, the [[Shakti|female power]] that emerged from Vishnu burned Muran to ashes with her glance. Vishnu, who was pleased, named the [[Devi|goddess]] 'Ekadashi' and asked her to claim a boon. Ekadashi, instead, beseeched Vishnu that people who observed a fast on that day should be redeemed of their sins. Vishnu thus declared that people who observed a fast on that day and worshipped Ekadashi, would attain Vaikuntha. Thus came into being the first Ekadashi, which was a Dhanurmasa Shukla Paksha Ekadashi.
The demon Muran stands for the Rajasic and Tamasic qualities in people, attributed to lust, passion, inertia, arrogance etc. When one conquers these tendencies, one attains the purity of mind, Satva, indispensable for attaining of moksha, the liberation or realization of the self. For realizing the self as pure awareness, purity of mind is required. Fasting helps to keep at bay tendencies which could be triggered by intake of certain foods. Keeping vigil in the night is symbolic of awareness, or being watchful of the contents of the mind. When the mind is looked at, it becomes still. To abide in the stillness is to attain freedom or peace, acquired through merging of the mind with the self. This is symbolic of the mind automatically being absorbed at the sight of Vishnu after the arduous fast and vigil.
The belief that rice is prohibited, because Muran dwells in it, symbolically signifies that the eating of rice makes one feel heavy and hampers the vigil. This signifies that entertaining negative tendencies could hamper one's progress towards awareness or consciousness. Observance of the rituals on this auspicious day even without understanding their importance is beneficial. Hence the merit accrued through observing them with piety is believed to be immeasurable. In the ''[[Mahabharata]]'', ''[[Bhagavad Gita]]'' the conversation between Krishna and [[Arjuna]] at the beginning of [[Kurukshetra War]] is said to have occurred on this day.
==Fasting on Ekadashi== Vaikuntha Ekadashi fasting is an important aspect of those associated with it. People fast the whole day and keep vigil. Special prayers are offered to Vishnu and devotees engage in Japa (chanting of Vishnu's name) and Dhyana (Meditation). On 'Dashami', the previous day of the observance, devotees who take up Vaikuntha Ekadashi fasting are to take only lunch. On Ekadashi, the next day, they have to maintain a complete fast and engage in prayers and meditation of Vishnu. They are strictly prohibited from taking rice. That night, people keep vigil the whole night and visit the temple of Vishnu, mostly in the wee hours of the morning.
On this day, the Vaikuntha Dwaram or the Vaikuntha Vaasal, 'The Gates of Vaikundam' are believed to be kept open. The area encircling the sanctum is referred to Vaikuntha Vaasal and devotees throng to gain entry into the temple, to seek Vishnu.
==Celebrations== ===Sri Rangam=== [[Sri Ranganathaswamy Temple (Srirangam)|Sri Ranganathaswamy Temple, Srirangam]] Vaikuntha Ekadashi celebrations in [[Srirangam]] last 20 days, divided into two parts: ''pagal pathu'' (morning part 10 days) and ''Ira pathu'' (night part 10 days). Vishnu as Lord [[Ranganatha]] Molavar will bless devotees in 'Muthangi' an armor of Pearls on all 20 days. On the 10th day of Pagal Pathu (previous day of Vaikuntha Ekadashi) Utsavar Namperumal will blesss devotees in Mohini Alankaram.
On Vaikuntha Ekadashi very early morning, Utsavar Namperumal will bless devotees in an armor of diamonds (rathnaangi) and brought to the Thousand-Pillared Hall from the sanctum sanctorum through the northern gate known as Paramapada Vasal, the gate to Vaikuntha. This gate is opened once in a year, only on the Vaikuntha Ekadashi day. It is said that any one who goes through the Paramapada Vasal will reach vaikuntham. On the 8th day of Irapathu Namperumal will bless devotees in Golden Horse Vahanam in the evening & Thirumangai Mannan Vedupari Ritual will be held<ref>{{cite web|last1=K|first1=Kandaswamy|title=Srirangam Vaikunta Ekadasi - Pagal Pathu, Irapathu Schedule This Year|url=https://skanda-news.blogspot.com/2016/12/when-is-vaikunta-ekadashi-this-year-date-srirangam-tirupati-schedule.html|website=Live Trend|publisher=K Kandaswamy|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
===Tirupati=== [[Tirumala Venkateswara Temple]] also has a similar concept to celebrate ''Mukkoti Ekadashi,'' as it is known as in the Telugu-speaking regions. [[Tirumala]] has a special entrance called ''Vaikuntha Dwaram'' that encircles the sanctum sanctorum. The ''dwaram'' (passage) is opened only on Vaikuntha Ekadashi and it is believed that any person who passes through this `Vaikuntha Dwaram' on this particular day attains [[salvation]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2001/12/27/stories/2001122703090300.htm | title=Fervour marks Vaikuntha Ekadasi | publisher=[[The Hindu]] | date=2001-12-27 | accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref> The temple witnesses heavy inflow of pilgrims and dignitaries for Vaikuntha Ekadashi. All Arjitha sevas are cancelled on this day, including VIP darshan and only Sarva Darshanam is allowed on Vaikunta Ekadashi except VVIP's. No Online Bookings are permitted on this day. Privileged darshan formats are stopped during this period.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tirumalatirupationline.com/tirumala-vaikunta-ekadashi-darshan-timings-story/ | title=All You Should Know: Tirumala Vaikunta Ekadashi | publisher= Tirumala Tirupati Online | date=2017-12-16 }}</ref>
